author: Rodney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2021
review_content: The fit is true, the upper and sole are great.  The insole is crap and is clued in with the intent to have it stay.  This is not a good idea.  The insole that comes with the shoe is just a cloth covered flat foam that offers no support.  If you have high arches, planter fasciitis, or other foot condition requiring specialized support this shoe is not for you.  If you pull out the insole before wearing it to put in an insole product you trust, you might be okay. Emphasis on "might" because they put a lot of clue on the insole the provide.  If you wear the shoe to try it out first, like I did, the pressure from your foot will fuse the insole to the shoe's foundation.  From there I had to slowly tear out the insole in pieces, being careful not to disturb the surface of the sole's foundation; rather labor intensive.  I replaced the worthless insole with the Easyfeet insole that I removed from my old shoe and now I am happy.  However, I will not be purchasing this shoe again because going through all that is just too much inconvenience.  It is too bad as everything else about the shoe is great.Addendum May 20, 2021:  I wear this shoe primarily for walking and running on my treadmill 5 to 6 days a week.  I have had the shoes for 5 months now and the right shoe has worn out in the heal, which caused a nasty blister on my foot. This is not the way my shoes usually wear out and hasn't happened in many years; this is my first Under Armour shoe. From the pictures I have included you can tell that the shoe has not been abused. The sole does not show much wear, which is what you would expect for 5 months. The heal on the inside is a mess however, as is the blister on my foot. Needless to say, it is clear that this is not a great shoe and I would not recommend it to anyone. including someone I didn't like.  I changed my rating to a one star because this review platform doesn't offer anything lower.
title: The Shoe is Great, the Insole Not So Much (5/20/2021 Addendum: Shoe is not great after all)

author: CT Cowboy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2021
review_content: After struggling with these shoes since the day I bought them, I cannot fathom the love for these sneakers. I'm in shock that the reviews are as good as they are. If you're like me and think that the universal praise for this shoe along with an unbeatable price point is just too good to be true, just know that it is.I bought these shoes in early February of this year. I am an active person who puts their footwear through a decent amount of abuse, but this brand and model are marketed as being able to handle that. When I got the shoes, I was pleased with how the shoe looked and felt. For what it is worth, these are good looking shoes for an incognito life. I didn't have any problems getting in to the shoe, and I wanted to take them out right away. When I stood up and took my first steps, the shoes immediately dug into the back of my heel, a feeling I would become very familiar with in the coming months. The shoes fit me properly, I had the right size. I figured I just had to break them in for a week or two and then I'd be sitting pretty in my new shoes.This "break in" period lasted months. I've been wearing these shoes everyday since February until August and except for a week in late April where they mysteriously felt comfortable, these shoes have consistently made my ankles bleed. I have scars from refusing to give up on these shoes. I tried doubling or even tripling up on tube socks, I tried manually pressing the heel back for hours to try and make it less sharp. My socks are glorified blood napkins because of these shoes. My friends suggested I ditch them entirely or invest in some protective socks but I was not going to do that because of my pride. Because of that pride I will have scars on my ankles for life. I've become less active because I don't want to put these shoes on and therefore less happy. I even delegated them to being work shoes but at the end of the day I hate these shoes. I will never skimp on footwear ever again. Maybe I just got bad ones, but hell, these are the worst shoes I've ever worn.
title: The Worst Shoes I've Ever Owned

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I've been using this shoe for about five years now, and though it lacks proper support for strenuous activity, this can easily be remedied with any kind of insert designed for that activity.The reason I'm docking so many stars now is because, after having used this shoe with minimal problems for five years, I expected similar results with a new pair of the exact same kind. However, this new pair only lasted a few weeks before breaking in the same way my old pair did.Both pairs broke the same way: the fabric at the back of the heel ripped. This wouldn't necessarily be a problem if there weren't jagged plastic edges directly behind this thin layer of fabric, which then inevitably dig into the back of your heel as you walk or run. I tried putting up with it for a while, but my blisters will tell you it's better to just buy a new pair.tl;dr This shoe is good, but doesn't really come ready-to-use out-of-the-box, and may only last you a few weeks.
title: Fair Shoe, but can Break Fast

author: Alex H

author: Scot Holmes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2020
review_content: Update: I guess I have a tall left foot (cartilage \ bones) I have to skip one crossover with the laces, midway up or that foot starts to really hurt. There is are really good webpages showing different shoe lacing techniques (I used info from Rick's sporting goods website). Still 5 stars for these shoes.My feet measure: 10.5" long x 4" wide & I'm flat-footed (always).These in Size 10 fit me very well in width, but a bit of extra wiggle room for my toes. I might have been able to go with size 9.5, but I didn't want to risk the return shipping times (long! due to covid-19).I am replacing a pair of Charged Assert 6 which I bought from a thrift store late last year (2019), they were made in Indonesia, January 2017. Most comfortable shoes I have ever worn until putting on these brand new Assert 8s (made in Vietnam, February 2020).I'm in my late 40s, most of my life I'd go to Academy & buy a pair of basic white Nike sneakers, without trying on other brands or styles, I loathed shopping. (Nike has given me more than enough reason to never give them my money again). With the quality and comfort of my 'well used' thrift store Assert 6s I feel I have made a great purchase at this price point. Also feels like I have been cheating myself, my feet & lower back for several decades, but that (& Nike) are in my past.I'm a walker not a runner so I can't say if they are 'good' for you running types. I have walked several hundred miles in my old pair, I'm certain these new 8th gens will perform just as well along with looking much better. ;-)
title: Love these shoes, I recommend them to others. Although I do need to tie laces differently.

author: Ben Couse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2021
review_content: Podiatrists will tell you that the most important factor in a supportive shoe is the shank - the center of the sole, between the ball and the heel.  It should be rigid.  Shoes shouldn't fold or roll up like a burrito.  These are decently rigid; you could fold them if you really wanted to, but they feel like they hold their shape pretty well under a run.  They're quite flat on the inside, but the thin foam insert is just like a sticky pad, you can pull it right out with no problem.  Get some comfy, supportive inserts or orthotics and you've got a decent running shoe for the price.  People complaining that they didn't last long... Well, they're running shoes.  If they last forever, you're not using them.
title: Not bad!  Worth a try!
